text: it's really an honor to be here and be a

young scientists so thanks to the whole
CD News team for this opportunity to
share with you some of the research that
my groups getting started at the
University of Michigan and also a bit
about my personal journey to this point
in my career which has been a bit fun to
reflect on it's not often you get the
opportunity to tell tell your story when
you get to get up at ACS and so thinking
back on how I got into science it's
actually surprising that I'm here today
because as I was growing up I envisioned
my future career would look something
like this I thought I was gonna be a
lawyer I went to Michigan started as a
political science major I envisioned
going to law school me becoming a judge
someday but all of that changed when I
took intro organic chemistry completely
by accident in this huge lecture hall I
just fell in love with science and for
the first time could envision a career
as a scientist and I think it was really
the combination of the creativity that's
required and thinking about how you can
build complex molecules or in this case
a simple molecule that you need this
creativity along with the knowledge and
the fundamentals of reactivity in order
to solve these types of problems and so
for me organic chemistry was really a
gateway to think from going to thinking
from thinking about small molecules to
thinking about more complex molecules
and some of the most complex
structurally intricate molecules that we
have to study are made by nature right
so these come to us from a variety of
different sources these natural products
can be isolated from plants microbes as
well as fungal sources and provide us
with these beautiful structures huge
puzzles to think about how we could make
these molecules in the laboratory but
what well it was structure that really
got me interested in natural products it
was learning about the biological
activity in the significance of natural
products and medicine that has really
made me stay in this area one of the
stats that still blows my mind and I
always question like is this real is
that 50% of all FDA approved drugs argue
their natural products or structural
derivatives of natural products and I
think just really just speaks to the
impact
of these malls that the impact that
these molecules that have had on drug
discovery over time and so my training
has always been in this area of natural
products research and where I started
out as a synthetic organic chemist where
a natural product is a starting point
for a project or then you design a
synthetic strategy where how we
basically outlining how you want to
build that molecule in the lab and from
there you go into the lab and try to
execute that synthetic strategy and some
of you that have worked in this area
might have had the experience like I did
then when you go into the lab and try to
build that molecule you find that
sometimes what you've drawn on paper
doesn't actually work and you devote you
to develop new synthetic transformations
in order to reach your natural product
target and so I've also approached the
area of natural product science from the
perspective of bio synthesis in learning
how nature is able to put together these
complex natural products um so here the
natural product is all also the starting
point for a project from here we can ask
questions like what makes a bio what
organism makes a given natural product
and also what genes encode for the
production of that natural product and
then studying the individual enzyme
mediated transformations that are
responsible for stitching these
molecules together and so it's this
field biocatalysis or the study of
enzyme mediated reactions where my group
is squarely focused and so our mission
is to develop bio catalytic reactions
that have enough synthetic utility that
they can cross over into mainstream
synthetic organic chemistry and so
biocatalysis is by no means a new field
there are beautiful examples of
biocatalysis being used in industry
literally to produce millions of tons of
commodity chemicals every year as well
as you'll see biokinetic processes used
to generate small chiral building blocks
which are then the starting point for
the synthesis of fine chemicals as well
as pharmaceuticals in a really exciting
direction impact biocatalysis which
we're seeing more and more examples of
are bio transformations on molecules
that are more structurally complex and
so one of my favorite examples of this
comes from Merck synthesis of januvia
type 2 diabetes drugs where they're able
to transform this ketone into a chiral
amine using a transaminase process I
think this highlights some of the major
advantages of biocatalysis and that
these are highly tuneable catalysts that
you can evolve to have extraordinarily
high efficiency high total turnover
numbers in these reactions these are
scalable processes that can be done on
the commercial scale I like to always
make the argument that bio catalytic
reactions are actually very accessible
to synthetic chemists I think some
people think like oh you need to be like
a biologist in order to work with
enzymes but really doing a bio colonic
reaction can be as simple as weighing
out a lot of wise enzyme like you would
any other solid region into a round
bottom flask to do your reaction but
perhaps one of the most compelling
reasons to choose a bio kinetic process
um is that these reactions tend to have
an excellent sustainability profile
which then can translate into economical
advantages so with this list of all the
reasons biocatalysis is so great
you might right now be asking yourself
why don't we build every molecule we
need to make using bio kinetic processes
because I asked myself this all the time
but there's actually a simple answer is
that while we have extraordinarily
extraordinary bio catalysts that are
used we simply don't have the breadth of
reactions available to us using bio
catalytic processes that we do using
traditional synthetic reactions and so
in other words we're currently in
biocatalysis living in the Oregon Trail
days right and we need to invent new

that biocatalysis has to offer and move
into the era of Pokemon go alright so my
group looks to do this by going back to

already has given us all the tools to
build these complex molecules we just
need to tap into those and with advances

identify the organism that produces the

can be as simple as sequencing the

us the blueprint for how nature builds a

useful so we're interested in a number
of different transformations to develop
biokinetic solutions and one of those is
the conversion of a carbon hydrogen bond
into a carbon oxygen bond we're
interested in this reaction for a number
of different reasons but two of the main
reasons are that installing a hydroxyl
group on a complex molecule can
radically change the biological activity
of that molecule
additionally installing a hydroxyl group
can serve as a functional handle to do
further chemical manipulations forward
and we think that enzymes have an
excellent role in this field because
they can offer orthogonal orthogonal
selectivity to what can be achieved
using more traditional synthetic methods
so these are some examples of molecules
where the hydroxyl groups are installed
enzymatically and the natural products
and you can see that they're able to
pick out a specific CH bond from many CH
bonds in a given molecule with excellent
site selectivity and stereo selectivity
okay so once we have identified a

developing a method for the next step is
to understand how that enzyme operates
within the context of its natural
biosynthetic pathway this is an example
of the higher level oxidation state of
taxall where each of these hydroxyl
groups are installed in the site and
stereoselective men are enzymatically so
where are the first question that we
want to ask is what enzyme does this
hydroxylation or which enzyme does this
hydroxylation in identifying the
function of each of these enzymes
enables us to think about doing a chemo
enzymatic synthesis of these very

using traditional chemistry and in the
context of the synthesis of these types
of molecules the Barren lab has
demonstrated that they can accomplish a
gram scale synthesis
of this taxa dynein molecule but then we
want to use enzymes to do the chemistry
that's challenging for chemists to
achieve using more traditional tools so
we start by chemically synthesizing this
deoxygenated version and then add
hydroxylation using our enzymes so we
also want to go beyond operating on
molecules that are the natural substrate
for a given enzyme to really exploit the
full potential of biocatalysis and so
this is a classic can be a classic
limitation to doing biocatalysis because
these enzymes have evolved operate on
one substrate with highest selectivity
and now we're saying we wanted to
actually operate on a whole range of
molecules so how do we get how do we get
our enzymes to do that and so we start
by evaluating what the substrate scope
is of the natural enzyme and it turns
out that some enzymes really only like
to operate on one substrate but we find
that a number of enzymes that we work
with in the lab actually operate on
quite a breadth of substrates and so
there the goal is to figure out what's
the limitation what's the steric
limitation to what types of molecules
that give an enzyme will operate on in
the electronic limitations of that as
well
I mean once we kind of define like the
limitations we use different strategies
in order to push beyond those limits so
one approach we like to use is substrate
engineering and this is an example from
the picker mice invited synthetic
pathway there's actually a graphic
that's not showing up here but that's
okay so essentially what happens is this
tertiary amine is responsible for

knowing that about the natural mode of

an enzyme we can copy that an engineer
an unnatural substrate that can also
bind into the enzyme active site so here
we maintain a tertiary amine in this
unnatural substrate and that is
successful in getting this molecule to
buying into the enzyme active site and
displaying only a single CH bond to
undergo a site in serious
active hydroxylation reaction so this is
maybe more specific example of how we
can expand the substrate scope but a
strategy we like to use which is perhaps
more general is protein engineering so
this is a crystal structure this is so
exciting that my lab just got a few
weeks ago of an oxygenase that we're
working with in the lab and this crystal
structure is an excellent starting point
for us to think about rationally
engineering our protein in order to
incorporate new types of substrates and
so this is a flavin mono oxygenase that
does a hydroxylation reaction on a range
of different substrates and my graduate
student summer has essentially given
this thing 40 different substrates to
work with and it processes about 25 of
those and so the question with the 15
that don't work are why and we found
that there's a trend that substrates
that our certain size just don't seem to
don't seem to get processed and so we
think that there's a steric limitation
to what our enzyme can accommodate in
its active site so looking at the
crystal structure we're able to identify
specific residues which might be
creating more steric congestion in the
active site and then mutate those and
once we've done that now we find that
not all 15 of those those traits that
didn't work before are now hydroxylated
but the majority of them are so we think
that this is another very fruitful
approach i'm so in addition to expanding
the substrate scope to do hydroxylation
reactions we're also interested in
developing new types of reactions and so
you can imagine in the CH oxygenation
reaction this oxygen atom is coming from
molecular oxygen and if we deprive the

different types of functionalisation to
form a c x bond where X might be a
different type of hetero atom or another
carbon and so I'll just note that this
type of strategy has recently been
successfully applied to cytochrome p450s
and by a number of different groups and
we think that this is a general strategy
that's going to be very powerful in
biocatalysis
so I think that using this combination
